Yeah, I think I’m going to make some strings that are longer and see how they work. I can’t even imagine a character limit of that long. I’m using this for the purpose of creating a json string in a property that will total up deals/line items/quantity and need to do this for some time periods like all time and past year. I imagine if there are a lot of deals I would get into a limit at some point, but it seems to not exist

limit always exists) maybe a few millions or billions characters on DB level

<https://share.zight.com/nOuJdeq4>

it is notes_last_updated - you can get this through the ui by going to the object properties and then clicking the internal name

this document has 66,833 characters — <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1jrxRsb9Jiznzau0iuXJ9JBVYoJaa0MEY-TYHbl8TOJo/edit?usp=sharing>

I was going to do some tests on this but this string is too long to manage in postman, I should likely use code to make this string work, but overall just looking at the google doc at 18 pages, it is safe to say that the amount of characters is likely more than enough for me to work with and I don’t need to test actual db limits

Hey all, has anybody had recent experiences, when creating a new tax through the tax api and associating this with a quote, sometimes, even though 200 ok response, when opening the quote builder, the tax doesn’t appear, it happens very inconsistently, any thoughts on this? also is it the same when doing this for discounts and fees?

But I am getting an error "`notes_last_updated` is a read only property; its value cannot be set"

Is there any way to make this editable?
no, this is set by HubSpot. You would need to create another property for this if you want to update it. HubSpot writes to that property and only allows read access

```Is it possible to update the contacts object and create associations in a single API call?```
No
You need to use association API to update associations

Last night, we had exactly 10,000 POST API requests come in to the /crm/v3/objects/contacts endpoint, with no name or email address associated with it. It did, however associate a property which pushed them through our workflow and set all 10k nameless/email-less contacts as marketing contacts. I can see all 10k POST api request in the logs but it gives me no information about the API call except for a Request ID. My application has only two functions, look up a user to get it's current HubSpot information and PATCH updates to existing contacts. I have already recycled my API keys, but I need to try and find some information about these API calls so I can stop a future incident.
Is there anyway to retrieve an IP address or any other indication for where the request originated from, or even to see the payload that was sent?

I am trying to find the NPS question property to add it into API request parameter `properties` so that API will return the result of this property.
